docs.lead_paragraph: This story has a chance of ending happily. But it begins last fall in a mangy downtown apartment as Katy Yeager, seven months pregnant, stares at a syringe and the crumpled foil that holds $40 worth of heroin.

headline.main: Special Report: In the Heart of U.S. Opioid Epidemic, Help Finds Mother and Baby

docs.lead_paragraph: The 9-year-old Kentucky girl calls the woman "nommy" and bears her middle and last name. They lived in the same household until the girl was 4, and "nommy" once carried the child on her insurance plan.

headline.main: Same-Sex Adoption Case Challenges What It Means to Be Parent

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans are pressing for an end to the four-decade ban on exporting crude oil and further curbs on President Barack Obama's environmental agenda as part of a sweeping $1.1 trillion spending bill.

headline.main: GOP Seeks Curbs in Obama Environmental Agenda in Budget Bill
headline.print_headline: GOP Seeks Curbs in Obama Environmental Agenda in Budget Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: As part of Michelle Obama's healthy eating initiative, a group of major food retailers promised in 2011 to open or expand 1,500 grocery or convenience stores in and around neighborhoods with no supermarkets by 2016. By their own count, they're far short.

headline.main: Grocery Chains Leave Food Deserts Barren, AP Analysis Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: Why would an 82-year-old man kill his son, his daughter, his wife and himself?
docs.abstract: Eighty-two-year-old Franck Stack's killing of his ailing wife and intellectually-disabled adult son and daughter, followed by his own suicide, in Elmhurst, Ill, has left some puzzling over his motive; some speculate that Stack feared for treatment his children would receive in group homes where they resided after death of himself and his wife.
docs.snippet: Why would an 82-year-old man kill his son, his daughter, his wife and himself?

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican and Democratic negotiators closed in on a package of tax cuts for businesses and individuals that could exceed $700 billion in forgone revenues over a decade.

headline.main: Lawmakers Near Deal on Billions in Tax Cuts
headline.print_headline: Lawmakers Near Deal on Billions in Tax Cuts

docs.abstract: Congressional negotiators have almost come up with major tax cut package for businesses and individuals that would extend or make permanent about 50 temporary tax breaks due to expire or lapse; Republican and Democratic negotiators say they are intent on getting Congressional approval before end of year.
docs.snippet: Republican and Democratic negotiators closed in on a package of tax cuts for businesses and individuals that could exceed $700 billion in forgone revenues over a decade.

keywords.value: Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. D’Amato, a former United States senator, took a star turn at the federal corruption trial of a fellow Republican, State Senator Dean G. Skelos, and his son, Adam B. Skelos.

headline.main: Alfonse D’Amato in Rare Role: Testifying Against Friend at Skelos Trial
headline.print_headline: D’Amato in Rare Role: Testifying Against Friend

docs.abstract: Former United States Sen Alfonse M D’Amato takes witness stand in federal corruption trial of Dean G Skelos, former majority leader of New York Senate, and his son Adam B Skelos, testifying that he warned elder Skelos of his son's troublesome behavior at medical malpractice insurance company Physicians’ Reciprocal Insurers; forceful yet matter-of-fact testimony bolsters testimony of other witnesses, who claim that Sen Skelos used his influence to help his son professionally.
docs.snippet: Mr. D’Amato, a former United States senator, took a star turn at the federal corruption trial of a fellow Republican, State Senator Dean G. Skelos, and his son, Adam B. Skelos.

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and VIVIAN YEE

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. regulators have approved the first generic version of one of the first very effective — and expensive — cancer drugs, Gleevec, which costs about $10,000 a month.

headline.main: FDA OKs First Generic for Gleevec Leukemia Pill
headline.print_headline: FDA OKs First Generic for Gleevec Leukemia Pill

docs.snippet: U.S. regulators have approved the first generic version of one of the first very effective — and expensive — cancer drugs, Gleevec, which costs about $10,000 a month.
